The History of Mapping

From Caves to Cubes: A History of Mapping Light

Before the term video mapping existed, humans were already mapping the world through light and surface.

In the depths of the Grotte de Lascaux, Chauvet and Pech Merle in France, the first image-makers discovered that the irregular shapes of the cave walls could become part of the image itself.

The convexities of rock became the flanks of a bison, the shadow of a torch made an animal appear to move.

These early artists were not just painting; they were mapping — using the architecture of the world as a canvas, embedding illusion within matter.

The rock surface was not neutral background but a collaborator, a primitive topology for representation.

 

 

Centuries later, this same dialogue between image and space found new expression in the Renaissance.

The discovery of linear perspective by Brunelleschi and Alberti was, in essence, a mathematical form of mapping — a way to project three-dimensional reality onto a two-dimensional plane.

Artists like Pere Borrell del Caso, with his 1874 painting Escaping Criticism, pushed the illusion to its paradoxical limit: the figure literally steps out of the frame. The painted world invades the viewer’s world.

The image reclaims space. This is the spirit of trompe-l’œil — a trick of the eye that anticipates every future experiment where image and reality blur.

 

 

By the Baroque era, illusion expanded beyond the canvas to encompass whole architectures. The frescoes of Andrea Pozzo at Sant’Ignazio in Rome transformed ceilings into infinite heavens, merging painting, perspective, and built space.

Churches became immersive environments — proto-domes of projection — where light and geometry conspired to suspend disbelief.

The human eye was now inside the image.

 

 

With the twentieth century came the dematerialization of image and matter.

The paintbrush gave way to the projector. French architect and artist Hans Walter Müller, beginning in the 1960s, developed inflatable architectures and projected diapositives onto their translucent membranes, sometimes inside natural caves, calling theses "topoprojections".

His environments breathed, expanded, and glowed — living architectures of light. Müller’s work fused the ephemeral and the structural, prefiguring the “mapped” light architectures that would come decades later.

 

 

In the 1980s, American artist Michael Naimark introduced a crucial shift: the feedback loop between real space and projected image.

In his project Displacements (1980–84), he filmed a domestic scene using a rotating camera, then projected the same footage back into the same space using a rotating projector. The result was uncanny — a ghost of the recorded world haunting its original location.

Time, memory, and perspective were mapped together. Here the image no longer represents space; it inhabits it.

Naimark’s moving projection becomes a spatial event — a living cartography of perception.

 

 

Parallel explorations emerged in experimental cinema and performance art: Krzysztof Wodiczko projected faces of marginalized voices onto urban monuments, politicizing architecture through illumination.

His works redefined the relationship between body, space, and image — each was a step toward mapping as a live, spatial, and social practice.

 

 

By the 2000s, this lineage converged in the rise of video mapping, as digital technology enabled real-time alignment of image and architecture.

The artist-collective EXYZT, later evolving into 1024 Architecture, translated this long history of illusion into the language of pixels, code, and stage performance.

In Étienne de Crécy’s “Beats and Cubes” live shows (2007), they constructed a luminous cubic structure whose geometry was mapped with video and synchronized with electronic sound. The cube pulsed, folded, and unfolded in sync with the beat — architecture became instrument, façade became choreography.

The legacy of Lascaux’s shadows returned, now algorithmically controlled, projected on modular space instead of stone.

 

 

From 2010 onward, the story of mapping entered a new chapter with the creation of MadMapper, a software developed by artists, for artists.

Conceived by the Geneva-based studio GarageCube (creators of Modul8) in collaboration with 1024 Architecture, MadMapper distilled the complex craft of projection alignment into an intuitive visual interface.

What had once required specialized engineering became a fluid act of creation — drawing with light in real space.

This tool opened the field to a generation of designers, musicians, VJs, and visual artists, transforming mapping from an experimental niche into a widespread artistic language.

Like the pigments of Lascaux or the perspective grids of the Renaissance, MadMapper became the new brush of its era — a technology that democratized illusion, empowering anyone to sculpt space with light.

 

 

Today, mapping is no longer an illusion of depth on a surface — it is a method of composing reality itself.

From painted caves to digital architectures, each epoch redefined the link between image and world, light and structure.

The gesture remains the same: to reveal the hidden space between matter and vision, between seeing and being seen.

As the beam of a projector finds its surface, we are still in the cave, tracing the contours of the world with light.

MadMapper Recent Highlights

Meet MadMapper 6

 

Geneva, TBA, 2025

 

MadMapper 6 is now available to buy at Madmapper.com. Users who pre-ordered the v6 upgrade can now download it directly from the Downloads tab in their Account page.

 

This landmark update introduces powerful new tools for creators to experiment with their mapping ideas, perform more intuitively in live contexts, and synchronize entire shows with the brand-new Timeline feature. It’s been one of the most requested additions, and we’re thrilled to finally deliver it to the MAD community.

 

MadMapper’s interface has also received a refined visual overhaul. While everything remains where you expect it, the experience is cleaner, sharper, and more precise. For a quick tour of what’s new, explore the “MadMapper 6 at a Glance” page.

 

To support users worldwide, we’re also launching the new MAD Documentation platform, offering a clearer, more accessible learning experience than ever before. Alongside it, the MAD Certified program is now live on our website, making it easy to find and connect with certified artists, schools, and training partners across the globe.

 

Welcome to the new era of MadMapper!

Discover MadMapper v6 Highlights

(current infos and texts below from first MadMapper Beta 6 newsletter - November 2024)

Timelines

Take control of any parameter in a timely fashion! As simple as that. Bezier, Catmull Rom, Linear or not interpolated on the menu.

Montage Tracks

Create as many montage tracks as you like, as with non linear editing software. Cut, chop, arrange or time-reverse your medias the easy way. Before or once you’ve crafted your montage track, simply assign it to the surface of your choice.

Timelines grid

Multiple timelines offer the flexibility to improvise by managing various sequences and switching between them to respond to the moment. Additionally, you can define a trigger exclusivity: either horizontally or vertically, even on the whole grid for mutually exclusive timelines.

MAD conductor

It's the conduct of your entire show ! Its dedicated view lets you organize your entire project, providing the info your need at your fingertips. Another MAD news: you can now manage and synchronize your entire show with Midi Time Code (MTC) or Linear Time Code (LTC).

MAD clips

MadMapper 6 also introduces Clips : short, repeatable, and loopable segments. These are ghostable and can be consolidated as unique elements as well. It's a great way to manipulate your content !

Audio track

Audio tracks come with advanced FFT analysis, offering powerful new options for audiovisual synchronization. It provides a visually stunning and practical way to see audio frequencies, making it easier than ever to place triggers with precision. A wonder for syncing visual elements to specific frequencies or beats !

Markers

Within your timeline tracks, you can set up markers with follow actions to bring basic logic and interactivity to your timelines. Wait for specific events such as button presses, custom goto to jump to specific parts of your show based on different actions and so on... Booya !

Export

Another game-changer: you can now bake your entire mapping, including Laser, DMX, Video, and Audio elements, all in one go! Whether it’s your entire project or just a loop section, simply click the Export button in the top-right corner of the timeline and you'll get access to this export window including audio, video codecs settings, and more.

DMX outputs

DMX fixtures now sample directly within video surfaces ! Composite surfaces in realtime and convert your layer stack to light ! By default, this enables automatic DMX canvas generation, but for more accuracy you can also define a custom DMX canvas for pixel-perfect control. Plus you can create multiple canvas instances in the projectors tab.

Projects workspaces

We’ve significantly enhanced project structure capabilities, now embedded in a local workspace. So you create a project, save it, and instead of having a .mad project, you now get a local workspace hosting your entire project. The workspace includes everything ! From materials and media to auto-saves, making it easier than ever to keep all project elements in one clean, accessible location. Collect and save your ressources from the File menu, then simply copy this entire folder to transfer your project to another computer !

Offline library

No more reliance on online materials and fx ! When you first start MadMapper, your entire library downloads directly to your computer, making it so much more convenient for offline work. The Library tab therefore hosts all your materials and fx, giving you quick access whether you're online or offline !

Optimized UI

One more standout change: the media pool is now conveniently positioned on the left, right beside the surfaces in order to put everything you need within easy reach. One trick though - if you prefer the previous layout, you can switch back via the View / Separate Media Tab menu. However keeping media on the left greatly improves comfort and workflow when using the timeline !

Video Mapping

 

MadMapper is the reference software for real-time video mapping, combining an intuitive interface with professional technical capabilities.

 

It enables video and generative content to be projected onto simple or complex surfaces, thanks to many advanced mapping tools. Users can precisely map various content onto 2D and 3D volumes with total control.

 

The integrated video engine is ultra-high-performance, capable of handling very high resolutions and playing formats such as HAP, ProRes, standard H264 and more. It supports multiple simultaneous video outputs, making it ideal for immersive installations and large-scale events.

 

MadMapper also supports live sources via Syphon, Spout, NDI or camera feeds, and offers perfectly fluid playback, whether looped, triggered or timeline-driven.

 

The software also includes a full-featured shader editor, enabling the integration of generative effects in real time, and an audio engine that enables content or effects to be driven from sound (spectrum analysis, beat detection, etc.). Compatibility with standard protocols (MIDI, OSC, DMX/Artnet, Ableton Link) makes it a particularly connected and powerful creative platform.

Light Mapping

 

MadMapper gives you precise, creative control over light, thanks to its powerful MadLight feature. The software indeed natively supports DMX, Art-Net, or sACN protocols.

 

Its integrated LED scanner facilitates spatial calibration of installations, and coupled with video, audio or shaders, light mapping in MadMapper paves the way for dynamic, immersive and totally synchronized light scenography.

Hardware Essentials

MadMapper is designed to be lightweight, flexible, and compatible with a wide range of hardware configurations.

 

Whether you’re working on a small projection mapping project or a large-scale installation, here’s what you need to know about supported systems and recommended setups.

What You Need to Run MadMapper

At its core, all you need to get started with MadMapper is a computer. Also meaning even with the Demo version you can explore the interface, design your mappings, and experiment with ideas entirely on-screen.

 

If you plan to create projection mapping, you'll need a projector. Most modern models will work; brightness, throw distance, and lens options simply depend on your project’s scale. We break down the key considerations below.

 

For light and laser mapping, you’ll find additional recommendations and best practices in the dedicated sections further down.

 

And of course, be prepared with the usual essentials: video adapters, extension cables, power solutions, and other connectors depending on your setup. A well-organized toolkit goes a long way during live installations.

Supported Platforms

MadMapper v6 runs seamlessly on both macOS and Windows.

macOS: version 10.9 or higher

Windows: version 10 or higher

 

There is no “better” platform, both systems are fully supported and deliver excellent performance.

The choice usually depends on your personal preference, budget, and the type of projects you plan to create.

macOS Recommendations

MadMapper performs well even on modest Apple hardware, making it an excellent choice for portability and reliability.

  • Entry-level MacBooks (such as MacBook Air or older MacBook Pro models) are perfectly fine for comnon projection mapping tasks.

  • If you plan to work extensively with heavy shaders, multiple video inputs, large 3D content, etc. you’ll benefit from a more powerful GPU (graphics card).

  • Even a second-hand MacBook can be suitable for light to medium use.

MadMapper has been a native M-software for Apple Silicon (M-series) computers since version 5 and above.

Output considerations (macOS)

Modern MacBooks often feature limited video outputs (USB-C or Thunderbolt).

 

To connect multiple projectors or displays, you might need an adapter or splitter, such as:

  • Matrox TripleHead2Go

  • Datapath FX4 (a more advanced and reliable option)

  • StarTech multi-output adapters (affordable and practical)

Think of these devices as “video multipliers” that expand your available outputs.

MadMapper supports unlimited outputs with any license, the only limitation comes from your hardware setup.

Windows Recommendations

MadMapper runs equally well on Windows systems, as long as they’re properly configured.

  • Processor (CPU): Choose a recent, high-performance model (Intel i5/i7/i9 or AMD Ryzen series). Avoid entry-level CPUs, which can bottleneck performance.
  • Graphics Card (GPU): A dedicated GPU is essential. NVIDIA and AMD cards are both supported.
  • Memory (RAM): At least 8 GB is required; 16 GB or more is recommended for smooth performance.
  • Storage: An SSD drive is strongly recommended for faster project loading and video playback.

Even compact PCs such as Intel NUCs or mini PCs can handle projection mapping surprisingly well, it can be ideal for small or portable setups.

About MadMapper

 

Created and developed by 1024 architecture and GarageCube since 2010, the concept of MadMapper emerged during an early edition of the mapping festival in Geneva, when Frz from 1024 and Boris from GarageCube discussed about how to properly map a visual content in realtime, in real space.

MadMapper was therefore born from the encounter between an artistic label - 1024 - and a software development company - GarageCube -. The essence of the software is coming from this deep relationship between artistic needs and technical solutions to make the dream happen.

The core idea is to make the technical aspect of a digital installation as easy as possible, in order to focus on the creative matter rather than to spend hours on the setup.

MadMapper is an easy to use yet powerful tool to map video into the space, control lights and led bars, and, since version 5, to control and use laser beams in the same funny way and process.

Headed by 1024 in Paris / France and GarageCube in Geneva / Switzerland, the mad team grows up with a developper dream-team based in Brussels / Belgium and an international community of mad users.

The software is used worldwide by countless visual and digital artist, scenographers, stage designers, Vjs, and many others creative people to produce smart digital art installation or big shows in Las Vegas !

MadMapper is the tool that we dreamed of.

MadMapper, the ultimate mapping software

 

MadMapper is a leading software for video and light mapping used globally by visual artists, scenographers, and so on. Built for creative freedom and live performance, it allows users to map content onto any surface - flat or complex - in real time.

Key features include support for multiple outputs, advanced mesh warping, real-time video playback, audio reactivity, DMX/Art-net lighting control, and recently laser mapping, enabling users to control laser projectors with unprecedented accuracy and flexibility.

It remains highly accessible to newcomers, while offering deep customization for professionals. Therefore MadMapper is widely adopted by art schools, media labs, and training programs around the world, fostering a strong community of learners and creators who shape the future of audiovisual expression.

Video Mapping

 

MadMapper is the reference software for real-time video mapping, combining an intuitive interface with professional technical capabilities.

It enables video and generative content to be projected onto simple or complex surfaces, thanks to advanced warping, Bézier masking or multi-surface management tools. Users can precisely map video onto 2D and 3D volumes, with total control over distortion and content synchronization.

The integrated video engine is ultra-high-performance, capable of handling very high resolutions and playing formats such as HAP, ProRes, standard H264 and more. It supports multiple simultaneous video outputs, making it ideal for immersive installations and large-scale events.

MadMapper also supports live sources via Syphon, Spout, NDI or camera feeds, and offers perfectly fluid playback, whether looped, triggered or timeline-driven.

The software also includes a full-featured GLSL shader editor, enabling the integration of generative effects in real time, and an audio engine that enables video or effects to be driven from sound (spectrum analysis, beat detection, etc.). Compatibility with standard protocols (MIDI, OSC, DMX/Artnet, Ableton Link) makes it a particularly connected and powerful creative platform.

Light Mapping

 

MadMapper gives you precise, creative control over light, thanks to its powerful MadLight feature. The software indeed natively supports DMX, Art-Net, or sACN protocols.

Its integrated LED scanner facilitates spatial calibration of installations, and coupled with video, audio or shaders, light mapping in MadMapper paves the way for dynamic, immersive and totally synchronized light scenography.

MiniMad

 

MiniMad is an hardware plug-and-play device designed to playback your MadMapper setups with automatic network synchronization for multi-projection or DMX / Artnet output to control lighting and LED equipment.

 

MiniMad makes your installation easy and affordable: it hooks up to a projector and plays movie files on surfaces exported from MadMapper. Put your expensive and bulky computers out of a job.

Small by size but feature rich: with the tiny MiniMad, you export quad, triangle circle or mask surfaces as well as their content from a selected projector

in MadMapper. Or you can switch the MiniMad to lighting mode and output DMX/Artnet channel data to your light fixtures.

Discreet and Autonomous: the MiniMad can run on its own for a very long time: we have one unit in the lab running for more than a year! In case of a power failure, the MiniMad will automatically restart without any user intervention. All the mapping modifications you do are automatically saved on the SD-Card.

Team Power: multiple MiniMads can be synchronized with each other over ethernet to make a cluster of synchronized video players. Zero configuration needed! MadMapper will automatically split movies and optimize files for playback.

 

MiniMad Main Features

  • Automatic Synchronisation of video media playback when multiple MiniMads are connected to the same ethernet network.
  • In-Depth Quality Export with precise video controls.
  • Up to 64 universes for ArtNet/DMX.
  • Autonomous playback of content recorded from MadMapper.
  • MultiChannel Audio when using Light mode.
  • Native Video Playback up to 1080p30 in optimal conditions.
  • Physical controls with friendly buttons to tweak your mapping directly on location.
  • Video or Light. 2 playback modes available.
  • VideoWall easy setup one click full automated process.
  • Zero configuration, as simple as that.
  • Playback modes: loop, random, list... configure your MiniMad to playback your videos the way you want it.
  • Mesh Warping and Perspective Pinning with adjustable manual controls.
  • Remote control your MiniMads directly from MadMapper.

 

Technical Specifications

  • Raspberry Pi 2
  • 7 buttons control panel
  • 1x HDMI output up to 1080p (1920x1080 at 60Hz)
  • Size 9 x 6 x 3 cm (approx. 3.5 x 2.3 x 1.2 inches)
  • MiniMad is setup for either video mapping or light mapping; it cannot do both at the same time, otherwise you would need two different units.
  • Media playback (video) is automatically synced when MiniMad units are connected to the same ethernet network but it can induce a one-frame delay between the different units, therefore the device is not suitable for blending/soft-edge.
  • For MiniMads that will be running continuously for months, for example for an installation, we recommend using industrial-grade Micro SD cards + having backup SD cards with your project already exported.
